default.prompt: What are 'Patch Flags' in the Vue 3 rendering engine?
options: Flags used to identify which CSS files to load.
Small numerical markers generated by the compiler to tell the Virtual DOM exactly what needs to be updated in an element (e.g., just text, or just class).
A way to skip the component lifecycle hooks.
Errors that appear when a template is malformed.
default.explanation: During the compilation phase, Vue marks elements with flags. For example, if only the text is dynamic, Vue marks it with a TEXT flag, so the diffing algorithm doesn't waste time checking attributes or classes.
default.interviewTip: This is why Vue 3 is often called 'Compiler-Informed'. It moves the work from runtime to compile-time.

options: A way to make the app work on older browsers.
The process of moving static Virtual DOM nodes outside of the render function so they are created once and reused across every re-render.
Lifting the state to the parent component.
A method to increase the priority of an API call.
default.explanation: If a piece of your template is purely static (no variables), Vue hoists it. Instead of creating a new Virtual Node on every render, it simply points to the same pre-created node, saving memory and CPU.
default.interviewTip: Static Hoisting is one of the main reasons Vue 3 templates have near-zero overhead for static content.

default.prompt: Analyze the code snippet from a compiled Vue render function. What does the '1 /* TEXT */' represent?
options: The z-index of the div.
A Patch Flag indicating that only the text content of this div is dynamic.
The version of the Vue compiler used.
The number of children the div has.
default.explanation: This is a Patch Flag. When the Virtual DOM 'patches' this node, it sees the '1' and knows it only needs to check the text content, completely ignoring the attributes (null).
default.interviewTip: You can see these flags yourself by using the Vue Template Explorer online.

options: A way to organize files in a project.
A structure where dynamic nodes are tracked in a flat array within a 'Block', allowing the diffing algorithm to skip static branches entirely.
A tool for visual debugging.
The tree structure used by CSS Modules.
default.explanation: Vue 3 divides the template into 'Blocks'. Each Block knows which of its children are dynamic. When updating, Vue iterates over the 'dynamic children' array rather than traversing the whole tree.
default.interviewTip: This turns the Virtual DOM complexity from 'O(total number of nodes)' to 'O(number of dynamic nodes)'.

default.prompt: What does the 'nextTick()' function do in the rendering cycle?
options: It restarts the app.
It returns a promise that resolves after the next DOM update cycle has finished.
It speeds up the browser's clock.
It forces the browser to refresh the page.
default.explanation: Vue updates the DOM asynchronously. If you change a value and immediately try to measure the DOM, you'll get the old state. nextTick() ensures you are working with the updated DOM.
default.interviewTip: Common use case: Focusing an element after it was just shown with v-if.

default.prompt: Which of these are steps in the Vue 'Compiler' pipeline?
options: Parse (turning template string into an AST).
Transform (applying optimizations like hoisting and patch flags).
Generate (creating the final Render Function string).
Hydrate (connecting the DOM to the server state).
default.explanation: Hydration is a runtime process during SSR. Parse, Transform, and Generate are the three classic stages of the Vue compiler.
default.interviewTip: Understanding AST (Abstract Syntax Tree) is a 'Senior' level concept in frontend engineering.

default.prompt: In the Virtual DOM, what is a 'VNode'?
options: A native HTML element.
A Plain JavaScript object that describes what the real DOM element should look like.
A specialized server for Vue apps.
A variable stored in LocalStorage.
default.explanation: VNodes are lightweight. Creating and comparing thousands of VNodes is much faster than manipulating thousands of actual DOM nodes.
default.interviewTip: The collection of these VNodes is what we call the 'Virtual DOM'.

options: Vue downloads a security update.
The old Virtual DOM tree is compared to the new one, and only the necessary changes are applied to the real DOM.
The component is deleted from memory.
The CSS is re-compiled.
default.explanation: Patching is the 'reconciliation' phase. Vue uses an efficient algorithm to find the minimum number of steps to transform the old DOM into the new one.
default.interviewTip: In Vue 3, patching is 'bit-wise' thanks to the Patch Flags we discussed earlier.

default.prompt: What is the Virtual DOM and why does Vue use it?
options: A backup copy of the real DOM.
A lightweight JavaScript representation of the DOM that allows Vue to efficiently calculate minimal updates.
A security feature.
A debugging tool.
default.explanation: The Virtual DOM allows Vue to batch updates and minimize expensive DOM operations by diffing the old and new virtual trees.
default.interviewTip: Vue 3's Virtual DOM implementation is significantly faster than Vue 2 due to optimizations like static hoisting and patch flags.

default.prompt: What are patch flags in Vue 3?
options: Flags for debugging.
Compiler hints that tell the runtime which parts of a template are dynamic, enabling faster updates.
Security patches.
Feature flags for experimental features.
default.explanation: Patch flags are integers that encode information about dynamic bindings, allowing Vue to skip static content during updates.
default.interviewTip: This is one of the key optimizations that makes Vue 3 faster than Vue 2.
